description: From hot +‎ head. Compare English hotbrain (“a hothead”); Middle English hot-heorte, hat-heorte (“anger”), Old English hātheort (“furious, angry, irascible, passionate, ardent”, literally “hot-heart”).

entries.meaning: (derogatory) One who angers easily or goes in search of arguments or fights.
examples: The club was full of eager young hotheads who never seemed to be able to agree on anything.

entries.meaning: One who reacts quickly and without thinking carefully first
examples: Someone get this hothead out of here.
